evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 is a zirconium-base alloy containing $1 . 5 \%$ tin. $0 . 2 \%$ iron. $0 . 1 \%$ chromium, and $0 . 1 \%$ oxygen

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
evidence_span: The materials were produced in the form of $4 0 \mathrm { - g }$ buttons from a zirconium crystal bar

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
evidence_span: Melting was carried out in an arc furnace with a tungsten electrode, under a partial pressure of argon gas

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
evidence_span: The buttons were then converted to 0.5- to 1-mm-thick sheet, using a standard zirconium-alloy processing sequence, comprizing ingot breakdown, followed by heat treatment in the beta-phase field and cooling in argon, then two cold-rolling cycles, with intermediate annealing for $^ { 3 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at $6 5 0 \mathrm { { ^ \circ C } }$
process_step: converted, heat treatment, cooling, cold-rolling, annealing

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens cut from the sheets obtained in this way were treated for 2 to $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ at temperatures ranging from 600 to $1 0 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , and in most cases were rapidly cooled by water quenching

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
evidence_span: Iron additions varying up to $5 2 8 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$ by weight were studied in a $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 1 . 4 \%$ EY $\mathrm { S n } { - } 0 . 1 \% \mathrm { O }$ matrix
composition_raw: 1.4% Sn, 0.1% O, up to 528 ppm Fe

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_028_chunk1
